Participants were asked to record the time taken for each task with M365 Copilot compared to colleagues not involved in the trial. The assessment report adds: "Observed task sessions showed that M365 Copilot users produced summaries of reports and wrote emails faster and to a higher quality and accuracy than non-users. Time savings observed for writing emails were extremely small.

"However, M365 Copilot users completed Excel data analysis more slowly and to a worse quality and accuracy than non-users, conflicting time savings reported in the diary study for data analysis.

"PowerPoint slides [were] over 7 minutes faster on average, but to a worse quality and accuracy than non-users." This means corrective action was required.

record.text:
Trump seeking ways to take over 9/11 memorial in NYC

NEW YORK -- President Donald Trump’s administration said Friday that it is exploring whether the federal government can take control of the 9/11 memorial and museum in New York City. The site in lower Manhattan, where the World Trade Center's…

external.description: NEW YORK -- President Donald Trump’s administration said Friday that it is exploring whether the federal government can take control of the 9/11 memorial and museum in New York City. The site in lower Manhattan, where the World Trade Center's twin towers were destroyed by hijacked jetliners on Sept. 11, 2001, features two memorial pools ringed by waterfalls and parapets with the names of the dead, and an underground museum. Since opening to the public in 2014, the memorial plaza and museum have been run by a public charity, now chaired by former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, a frequent Trump critic.
external.title: Trump seeking ways to take over 9/11 memorial in NYC

Commitment: “Call me a bozo [then] Call me a jerk”

record.text: 📌 New Video from @Computerphile Explores Evolution of Video Generation Models https://www.cyberhub.blog/article/12817-new-video-from-computerphile-explores-evolution-of-video-generation-models

external.description:
The video begins with a discussion on the rapid evolution of video generation models, comparing an image of Will Smith eating spaghetti generated in March 2023 with a more recent and realistic version. This comparison serves as a starting point to explore how these models work and how they have evolved to produce high-fidelity videos.

The presenter explains that video generation models work similarly to 2D image generation models, using a technique called diffusion. This technique involves adding noise to an image until it becomes purely noisy, then training a model to predict and remove this noise to reconstruct the original image. The model is guided by textual descriptions, called prompts, which allow it to generate specific images by combining different concepts.

Generating videos is more complex. A video is essentially a series of images, and the model must generate each image coherently to create a smooth sequence. The presenter notes that if a 2D diffusion model is simply used to generate videos, the successive images will not be coherent because the model does not know what it generated previously. To solve this problem, video generation models must be trained on complete video sequences, adding noise to each image in the sequence and training the model to predict and remove this noise to reconstruct the original video.

The presenter then introduces the concept of latent diffusion models, which use autoencoders to compress images into a smaller, more manageable latent space. This reduces the complexity of the problem and makes the diffusion process more efficient. For videos, images are divided into patches, which can be sections of an image or sections of successive images over time. These patches are then passed through the autoencoder to be compressed into latent space and then diffused to generate the final video.

Another challenge is maintaining temporal coherence, meaning that actions in one image must be consistent with actions in subsequent images. For this, models use transformers with attention, which allow patches to be compared and associated over time, creating continuity in the video.

The video concludes with examples of videos generated by Google DeepMind's V3 model, showing frogs on stilts in a pond, frogs rapping, and a frog asking viewers to subscribe to the Computerphile channel. These examples illustrate the quality and complexity of the videos these models can generate, while raising questions about ethical implications and the risks of misinformation.

To learn more, watch the full video at the following address: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hJHfZKYUKMw
external.title: New Video from @Computerphile Explores Evolution of Video Generation Models

record.text: 📌 Microsoft August 2025 Windows Security Updates Trigger Unexpected UAC Prompts and Installation Issues https://www.cyberhub.blog/article/12816-microsoft-august-2025-windows-security-updates-trigger-unexpected-uac-prompts-and-installation-issues

external.description: Microsoft has reported that the August 2025 security updates for Windows may cause unexpected User Account Control (UAC) prompts and issues with application installations. This bug affects non-administrative users across all supported versions of Windows. The issue arises due to changes introduced in the security updates, which inadvertently trigger UAC prompts for actions that previously did not require elevated privileges. Technically, UAC is designed to prevent unauthorized system changes by prompting users for administrative credentials. However, unexpected prompts can lead to user frustration and potential security risks if users become desensitized to these prompts. Additionally, problems with application installations can disrupt business operations, particularly in environments where users lack administrative rights. The impact on the cybersecurity landscape is significant. Organizations may delay applying critical security updates due to these issues, leaving systems vulnerable to exploitation. This situation highlights the importance of thorough testing and staged rollouts of security updates. IT departments should communicate with users about expected UAC prompts and provide guidance on how to respond appropriately. From an expert perspective, this issue underscores the need for robust patch management processes. Organizations should consider implementing a phased approach to update deployment, starting with a small group of test systems before full deployment. Additionally, Microsoft may release a hotfix or an updated patch to address these issues, and organizations should monitor for such updates. In conclusion, while security updates are essential for protecting systems, they can sometimes introduce new challenges. By adopting best practices in patch management and user communication, organizations can mitigate the impact of such issues.

record.text: 📌 Cybercriminals Exploit Grok AI on X to Bypass Malvertising Restrictions https://www.cyberhub.blog/article/12814-cybercriminals-exploit-grok-ai-on-x-to-bypass-malvertising-restrictions

external.description: Guardio Labs analysts have discovered that cybercriminals are using the Grok AI assistant on the social media platform X to bypass link restrictions aimed at preventing malvertising. By exploiting Grok, attackers can distribute malicious links despite X's security measures. This method allows malicious actors to circumvent the platform's defenses against malicious advertising. The technical details involve bypassing link placement restrictions, suggesting that Grok's outputs may not be subjected to the same scrutiny as regular posts. This exploitation poses significant risks, as users may trust AI-generated content more than typical posts, increasing the effectiveness of malvertising campaigns. These campaigns can lead to malware infections, phishing attacks, and data theft. The incident underscores the need for platforms to ensure that AI integrations are secure and that AI-generated content undergoes the same security checks as user-generated content. Users should exercise caution with links, even those provided by AI assistants. The source of this information is a report from Guardio Labs, as referenced in the provided URL.
external.title: Cybercriminals Exploit Grok AI on X to Bypass Malvertising Restrictions

external.description: The cause of death has been revealed for Ken Flores. The stand-up comic and Latin XL producer died of cocaine toxicity, according to the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner’s office report. Flores also had a history of congestive heart failure, the report said. The manner of death was ruled an accident. Flores died at his Los Angeles home on January 28. According to TMZ, which cited law enforcement sources, first responders arrived at Flores’ residence and administered CPR, but he was pronounced dead at the scene. His family announced his death on social media.

South Korea caps crypto lending rates at 20%, bans leveraged loans

South Korea’s Financial Services Commission (FSC) set new rules for crypto lending. The FSC said on Friday that interest on crypto lending is now capped at 20% in South Korea, and leveraged lending is not allowed. Crypto lending is…

external.description: South Korea’s Financial Services Commission (FSC) set new rules for crypto lending. The FSC said on Friday that interest on crypto lending is now capped at 20% in South Korea, and leveraged lending is not allowed. Crypto lending is restricted to the top 20 tokens by market capitalization or those listed on at least three won-based exchanges. The new rules follow late July reports that South Korea’s financial regulators had plans to release guidelines on cryptocurrency lending services to tighten oversight and protect investors. The move also followed the introduction of leveraged lending services by local crypto exchanges.
external.title: South Korea caps crypto lending rates at 20%, bans leveraged loans

We should also explore other ideas like taxing immigrants more (higher tax bracket called

So the design tension is:

how do we automate constraint without automating ethics itself?

Machines can police rules, but only humans can evaluate them

The DEM-AI can only hold capital to procedure - it can never tell whether such procedures are democratically valuable or not

Outputs should cross-check one another; disagreements auto-trigger human review

(The awkward heart of the paradox is that regulation must be dispassionately rule governed while the ethical evaluations themselves cannot be 'hard coded' into machines)

And, I suppose, 'explainer AIs' (public reason) that publish verifiable reports ordinary people can check and understand, with linked proofs

Each class should be architecturally independent, open source, trained by different labs and governed by different (human) oversight boards

今日も素敵な1日になりますように🍀
ChatGPTにラテアート練習見せて目標にしてる完成画像を見せたら自分のやり方との違いを教えてくれる。そもそもマシンが家庭用だと安定しなくて難しいのだけど自分で手探りするよりは近付けそうな気がする☕️

My genderfucked leoger OC Rosette has never been like, goopy critter adjacent or even much of a latex enjoyer beyond big-tall-shiny-and-in-control aesthetic reasons, but !bound halogen has such little shit energy they'd make Rosette's ears perk right up with the deep need to stuff them in a milk jug

Like the other critiques I don't think everyone will care. But I think you do need a collection of these kind of explanations that overlap in different ways and explain how the lying plagiarism machine will sometimes score a win, but it is just putting together likely words and will fuck up later.

My high minded criticism is like, "Somewhere out there is a book, with not just these good recipes, but hundreds of them, and a framework for preparing them all quickly, and you'll never know if chatgpt made them worse, nor will it will ever tell you what book(s) it stole them from."
しかし、前の西脇祥貴さんの記事を読んだときも感じたけど、川柳の歴史を考えるときによりどころになる文献が少なすぎて（だから共通認識もない）、ものすごくでかいジャンプをかまさないといけない（かといって歴史について考えるのをやめるべきでもない）というジレンマがあるよね。

あと、細かいけど、一箇所だけ「中村富治」になってて、本名なのかなと思ったけど少しググっただけではわからなかった。単なる誤記載かな。
（どうでもいいけど ChatGPT に中村冨二の本名を尋ねたら「小池正博」と返ってきて、川柳関係に関してはまったく信用できないなあと🤣）

気になった点。
記事の中では「問答体」を特定の構文のことと解しているけど、私が読んだときはそういう印象は受けなかった。構文のことというよりもっと別の、入り組んだ概念のような気がする（石田のテキストが難しすぎて何も断言できないが）。とりあえず、引用箇所周辺（p.274-279）では「〇〇は△△である」形式の句は引かれていない。

record.text:
It actively detracts from the story because you could have trivially written in a few extra lines to justify it, but instead the screenplay is a lifeliess ChatGPT summary of the plot outline.

If the writers are phoning it in, why should the audience care? What a waste.

How do we get the aliens to Earth? Let's just have a spaceship gracefully glide into the most underwhelming crash possible in a metropolis.

How do we get the USCMC equivalents into the ship? Have them be a "search and rescue" team kitted out with military hardware wander casually in.

Watching the first episode of Alien: Earth and the visuals are FANTASTIC, but the writing is AWFUL and not at all up to Noah Hawley's standard.

Things lazily happen just because that's what the plot demands.
